(pos. prol. of OPCs) endogenous and exogenous CXCL1 induced the proliferation of OPCs, and this effect was mainly indirect, mediated through astrocytes. The study also identified that CXCL1 acted through the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK1/2) pathway, primarily activated in astrocytes. When stimulated with CXCL1, astrocytes released several cytokines, but only the release of interleukin-6 (IL-6) was completely blocked by inhibition of the ERK1/2 pathway.

DITPA promotes OL differentiation from OPCs and myelination. DITPA overrides SLC16A2 (MCT8) down-regulation to potentiate myelination. DITPA treatment upregulates OL-specific transcription factors in early OPCs (oligodendrocyte precursor cells)

methylation of the MBP promoter by DNMT3a can negatively impact the differentiation of oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) into mature oligodendrocytes that are capable of forming myelin, which is essential for proper nerve functins. Specifically, the interaction between BHMT and DNMT3a is important because DNMT3a is implicated in de novo methylation, which is required for remyelination.

(important for the the process of myelination) MBP mRNA must be transported to oligodendrocyte processes for myelination. hnRNPA2/B1, a protein essential for mRNA transport. causing impairment of hnRNPA2/B1 function leads to impaired myelination.

(structural components of myelin & pos. diff. of OPCs into Oligodendrocytes). observed in the human central nervous system (CNS) at developmental stages preceding myelination (so likely progenitors). involved in the regulation of early neurogenesis.  plays a role in the differentiation of oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPCs) into mature oligodendrocytes. Golli proteins were also found in microglia, the immune cells of the CNS, and early neurons of the developing telencephalon. may be involved in the initiation of the myelination process.

(pos. prol. and migration of OPCs, expressed by OPCs / Part of adherens junctions important for radial glia migration )OPCs undergo consecutive symmetric divisions to exponentially increase the progenitor pool size. Protocadherin-15 (PCDH15) mediates a repulsive behavior between OPC daughter cells after division, which serves to avoid local OPC accumulation and facilitate OPC proliferation. This repulsion is crucial for the broad distribution of OPCs across the cortex. / adherens junctions located preferentially at the ventricular zone of neuroepithelium cells, functioning to anchor the radial glia to the ventricular surface and maintain apical-basal polarity.
